entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French despis-, stem of despire, from Latin despicere, from de- + specere to look spy

def.dt: :to look down on with contempt or aversion despised the weak
:to regard as negligible, worthless, or distasteful

entry.pt: despise contemn scorn disdain mean to regard as unworthy of one's notice or consideration. despise may suggest an emotional response ranging from strong dislike to loathing despises cowards. contemn implies a vehement condemnation of a person or thing as low, vile, feeble, or ignominious contemns the image of women promoted by advertisers. scorn implies a ready or indignant contempt scorns the very thought of retirement. disdain implies an arrogant or supercilious aversion to what is regarded as unworthy disdained popular music.
